project: Ukraine Agriculture Recovery Inclusive Support Emergency (ARISE) Project
description: This use case example reflects a strategic implementation of accessible financial support mechanisms to bolster agricultural productivity in the face of adversity. In the context of the Ukraine Agriculture Recovery Inclusive Support Emergency (ARISE) Project, financial accessibility was addressed through a two-pronged approach aimed at enhancing the resilience and sustainability of the agricultural sector amidst significant challenges, including conflict and natural or man-made disasters. Firstly, affordable credit was made available to farms, facilitating capital investment and operational continuity. This component targeted the broader agricultural ecosystem, ensuring entities of varying sizes could access the financial resources necessary for recovery and future growth. Secondly, the project instituted a grant system specifically tailored for small farms, recognizing the disproportionate impact of crises on smaller scale operators and the vital role these entities play in local food security and rural economies. Both methods were instrumented through the Business Development Fund and the Ministry of Agrarian Policy and Food, ensuring tailored, effective deployment of resources. This dual approach not only aimed at immediate recovery needs but also at fostering a more resilient agricultural infrastructure capable of withstanding future crises, thereby contributing to the broader objective of maintaining inclusive agricultural production.

project: Improvement and Rehabilitation of Irrigation Systems Project
description: This use case example revolves around the comprehensive rehabilitation and modernization of the Radoniqi-Dukagjini Irrigation Scheme (RDIS), through a focused investment of EUR 8.35 million aimed at enhancing agricultural productivity and reducing operational inefficiencies. In the context of aims to bolster rural economic development in Kosovo, the initiative sought to improve and modernize irrigation services to diminish water losses and production costs, and foster the introduction of higher value crops within project locales. Specifically, the RDIS operates two distinct irrigation frameworks - the Radoniqi scheme, fed by the Radoniqi dam with its seven irrigation sub-systems, and the Dukagjini scheme, with its six sub-irrigation systems. Through sub-components like rehabilitation work to modernize and upgrade the RDIS and the employment of a Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) system, this method illustrates an innovative approach to enhance water use efficiency and ensure the sustainability of the irrigation infrastructure.

description: This use case showcases a strategic intervention aimed at bolstering water use efficiency and agricultural productivity through capacity building, with a dedicated fund of EUR 0.4 million. This holistic approach not only aimed at improving water utilization efficiency but also sought to uplift the overall agricultural output in the project area by equipping stakeholders with the requisite knowledge and tools.

project: Rodrigues Airport Project
description: This use case example showcases the comprehensive methodology employed for infrastructure development, specifically for airport expansion, on Rodrigues Island. In the context of enhancing transportation and logistical capabilities, the project team undertook the construction of a new airport runway and associated facilities designed in accordance with International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) standards. The project featured the construction of a new 2100m long by 45m wide runway, new taxiways, aircraft parking stands, and an apron expansion to accommodate increased aircraft capacity. Moreover, the development included essential support infrastructure such as stormwater drains, airfield ground lighting, control systems, and navigational aids. A significant emphasis was placed on energy efficiency and sustainability, with all new buildings designed to meet Level 1 EDGE Certification standards and fully electrified using renewable energy sources. This holistic approach to infrastructure development not only addressed the immediate needs of expanding the airport's capacity but also incorporated best practices in environmental sustainability and energy efficiency.

project: Rodrigues Airport Project
description: This use case example illustrates a multifaceted approach to sustainable territorial development focused on Rodrigues Island, aiming to enhance agri-food systems and water resources sustainability. In an effort to bolster local economies and improve food security, the project team provided technical assistance and financial support for key investments in agriculture and fisheries. Methods included enhancing extension services, improving post-harvest efficiency, fostering climate-smart technologies, and strengthening the value chains for local products while encouraging participation from women in these sectors. In terms of water resource management, small-scale infrastructure projects coupled with technical assistance promoted the adoption of Integrated Water Resources Management (IWRMD) practices. The initiatives ranged from protection and rehabilitation of water sources, including desalination plants, to the development of sanitation improvement plans. This progressive endeavor engaged local governments, rural communities, and the private sector, ensuring substantial community involvement and gender consideration in implementing a sustainable development strategy.

project: Rodrigues Airport Project
description: This use case depicts a strategic approach to fostering sustainable tourism within Rodrigues Island, encompassing several sub-components aimed at improving the tourism sector through promotion, skill development, and infrastructure enhancement. Initially, the project team conducted a thorough review of the current institutional capacities related to tourism, followed by a comprehensive program to improve strategic alignment, resource management, and service delivery, including the green certification of the island. An emphasis on developing a distinctive brand identity for Rodrigues was pursued through international consultancy, focusing on brand management, marketing strategies, and ensuring local handicrafts align with the new brand. Skill development programs specifically tailored for tourism-related professions were implemented to upgrade service standards and promote green sustainability practices, with particular attention to encouraging women's participation. Further, the project supported small businesses through matching grants for sustainable upgrades and focused on enhancing the tourism infrastructure to enrich the ecological and natural experiences for visitors. This holistic approach aimed at revitalizing Rodrigues' tourism sector while emphasizing environmental sustainability and gender inclusivity.

project: Additional Financing to Tunisia Emergency Food Security Response Project
description: This use case example highlights the initiative of procuring an approximate quantity of 25,000 metric tons (MT) of durum wheat to ensure continued access to traditional bread and other cereal products affordable for poor and vulnerable households. In the context of the Tunisian Emergency Food Security Response, faced with a consecutive fourth year of drought leading to critical grain shortages, the government found it challenging to secure grain purchases due to the country’s fragile economic condition. The additional financing project, supported by a grant of $11.16 million from USAID, aimed to alleviate the immediate wheat shortage by ensuring the supply of wheat for bread for poor and vulnerable populations. Leveraging processes and procedures from the parent project, this initiative focused on efficient procurement and delivery of wheat from global markets at optimal pricing for Tunisia. This strategy addressed both immediate food security concerns and a model for fast response to similar crises, highlighting a pragmatic approach towards sourcing essential food supplies during acute shortages.

project: Additional Financing to West Africa Food Systems Resilience Program, Phase 1
description: This use case example showcases the integration of digital advisory services into regional agriculture. In the context of preparing Togo for food crisis prevention and management, the project introduced a new activity aiming to strengthen the country's Food and Nutrition Security (FNS) information and monitoring system. This was complemented by the expansion of existing activities to enhance the Cadre Harmonisé and risk detection mechanisms. The method involved the strengthening of government departments responsible for agricultural statistics, enhancing their capabilities for nationwide surveys, data collection, processing, analysis, and dissemination. Furthermore, risk detection systems were upgraded to ensure timely and effective preparedness for and response to food crises, thereby fortifying the resilience of communities against climate shocks. A distinctive aspect of this approach was the development of a Food Crisis Preparedness and Response Plan aimed at bolstering disaster preparedness at the community level, covering all aspects related to data collection and processing, including field-level surveys linked to the Cadre Harmonisé.

description: This use case example highlights the efforts to enhance the sustainability and adaptive capacity of the food system's productive base. The project scaled up interventions from the parent project, focusing more intensively on improving nutrition outcomes. Activities within this component involved consolidating the regional agricultural innovation system by investing in equipment and knowledge pertinent to vegetable farming, and in educating the local populace about adopting climate-smart practices and nutrition. Specifically, it targeted youth and women to increase their participation and benefits from these initiatives. Another significant undertaking was the promotion of integrated landscape management to facilitate producers’ access to high-quality inputs, emphasizing crops with high nutritional value. Special consideration was given to women to bridge the gap in access to quality inputs. The project also introduced new activities supporting households in acquiring improved breeds, bolstering animal health, and enhancing the production and use of organic fertilizers and biopesticides. Such measures were aimed at fostering a more sustainable food production system that is resilient to climate variations.

use_case: Food Market Integration and Value Chain Development
project: Additional Financing to West Africa Food Systems Resilience Program, Phase 1
description: This use case example emphasizes the importance of integrating regional food markets and developing strategic value chains for enhancing food security. The project built upon activities from the parent initiative by disseminating market information and investing in market infrastructure. An innovative strategy was to extend the project’s reach beyond the originally targeted value chains (poultry, rice, and soybeans) to include vegetables, cowpeas, and roots and tubers, which are crucial for local nutrition and livelihoods. The activities aimed to facilitate trade across key corridors and consolidate the food reserve system. This involved scaling up support for the dissemination of market information to help farmers access local, regional, and international markets, and establishing productive alliances between producers and aggregators for better commercialization of agricultural products. Additionally, the project aimed to enhance storage infrastructure and adopt post-harvest processing technologies through matching grants. The focus on promoting standards for quality and packaging aimed to meet market demands, benefiting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), women and youth-led producer groups, and cooperatives within the targeted value chains.

project: Strengthening the Partial Credit Guarantee (PCG) Fund for small farmers in Ukraine (Strengthening the PCGF in Agriculture Project)
description: This use case example illustrates the efforts to financial support small farmers in Ukraine through the capitalization of the PCGF (Partial Credit Guarantee Fund). In the context of land reforms and the challenges imposed by war, the PCGF was established to provide partial credit guarantees to small farmers, enabling them to access financing. The project comprised a central component focused on injecting EUR 10 million into PCGF, aiming at fortifying its capacity to support credit-constrained farmers, hence enhancing long-term agricultural development and food security. The fund was planned to be disbursed in two tranches: the first, EUR 6 million, ensuring the PCGF reaches its legally foreseen capital, and the second, EUR 4 million, to be released once the PCGF is fully operational with an acceptable institutional framework. This financial model was developed as part of a broader effort not only to support Ukraine's agricultural sector amid ongoing conflict but also to bolster the framework for sustainable rural development by leveraging private capital.

project: Additional Financing to the Food System Resilience Program, Phase 2 Sierra Leone
description: This use case example focuses on Strengthening Regional Food Security through Integrated Landscape Management (ILM) as a part of Sierra Leone's Food System Resilience Program. In the context of addressing food insecurity and enhancing resilience to climate variability, the project scaled up interventions promoting climate-smart and nutrition-sensitive agricultural practices. The strategy encompassed developing ILM technologies for communal lands to bolster the natural resource base sustainably, alongside promoting nutrition-sensitive practices among vulnerable groups. Activities included training for the establishment of homestead and community vegetable gardens, support for women's groups in establishing horticulture value chains, and capacity building within relevant institutions. This comprehensive approach aimed at not only expanding the supply of nutritious food but also increasing dietary diversity and improving overall food security in the region.

This involved implementing emergency preparedness measures, improving healthcare facilities, and ensuring the availability of medical supplies and equipment necessary for dealing with COVID-19 cases. This part of the project focused on educating the community about COVID-19 prevention measures, encouraging adherence to health guidelines, and combating misinformation related to the virus. Lastly, the third component centered on bolstering implementation management, monitoring, evaluation, and coordination efforts to ensure the project's effectiveness and sustainability. project: Philippine Rural Development Project Scale-up
description: This use case example describes how the Philippine Rural Development Project (PRDP) successfully strengthened value chain analyses (VCA) and institutionalized their use by Local Government Units (LGUs) across the Philippines. In the context of improving agricultural and fishery enterprises nationwide, the PRDP leveraged VCAs in conjunction with edaphic and climate-based suitability criteria for the Department of Agriculture's LGU planning and investment. This initiative has significantly catalyzed the start-up and expansion of many micro, small, and medium-scale agri-fishery enterprises. Through the use of Provincial Commodity Investment Plans (PCIPs), the project created a planning platform for joint investments between the Department of Agriculture and LGUs, mainstreaming and leveraging support from other government agencies. Despite the achievements, there remains a need for further investments in Farm-to-Market Roads (FMRs) and other rural infrastructure to enhance production areas' connectivity with markets. The project's approach focuses on scaling up through fewer but larger outcome-based programs, emphasizing public good investments such as research and development infrastructure markets, and biosecurity.

project: Philippine Rural Development Project Scale-up
description: This use case example demonstrates the Philippine Rural Development Project's (PRDP) efforts in enhancing the connectivity of production areas with market centers. Throughout the project's implementation, the PRDP has constructed 324 climate-proof farm-to-market roads (FMRs) totaling 2380 kilometers, alongside 45 bridges and several postharvest facilities meeting climate-proof standards. These infrastructures are pivotal in improving the accessibility of production hubs to markets, thereby fostering economic development in rural areas. The Department of Agriculture (DA) has become the key agency responsible for providing these FMRs and bridges, with effective processes mainstreamed for ensuring their operation and maintenance by Local Government Units (LGUs). These achievements have significantly influenced the design and priorities of the PRDP Scale-Up, aligning with higher-level objectives such as developing a competitive, sustainable, and technology-based agricultural sector. The focus on infrastructure development is also expected to contribute to greater national food security, job creation, increased farmer incomes, and resilience to climate change, among other key actions highlighted in governmental strategic agendas.

description: This use case example demonstrates the approach to enhancing agri-food development by improving rural community infrastructure. In the context of developing countries, one critical aspect of stimulating agricultural productivity and economic growth is the development and modernization of rural infrastructure. The project focused on investments in small community-/farmer-led irrigation developments, rehabilitation of rural feeder roads, local agricultural markets, and optimizing existing wastewater treatment systems for agricultural reuse. By implementing these measures in coordination with the Green Plan, unions of municipalities, and the Ministry of Agriculture, the project aimed to support agricultural activities effectively. Operation and maintenance of these infrastructures were ensured through collaborative efforts with local governing bodies, highlighting the importance of local ownership and participatory processes in project success. The initiative stood out for its dedication to regionally balanced fund allocations, evaluated through a participatory process against established criteria focusing on poverty impact, level of agricultural activity, climate co-benefits, and sustainable operation commitments.

description: This use case example discusses the strategy implemented to enhance social resilience in Ghana by addressing gender inequities in agriculture. In the context of the Ghanaian agricultural sector, women contribute significantly to labor but face notable disparities in asset ownership, financial access, and representation in farming organizations. The project undertook a multifaceted approach to empower female farmers and participants in the agricultural value chain. It aimed at providing equal access to productive resources, formal financial services, and leadership roles in farmer-based organizations (FBOs). Strategies included ensuring women could own farms at rates closer to their male counterparts, improving women's access to formal financial services, and increasing their representation in both upstream and downstream agricultural activities. By targeting these areas, the project not only sought to close the gender gap but also to improve overall agricultural output and household welfare, taking into account that equipping women with similar resources as men could potentially raise agricultural productivity by up to 30 percent and national agricultural output by 4 percent.

project: Additional Financing to the  Central African Republic  (CAR) Emergency Food Crisis Response Project
description: This use case example outlines the methodological approach taken in the Central African Republic (CAR) Emergency Food Crisis Response Project to enhance agricultural productivity and livestock health to increase food production and improve the resilience of targeted smallholder farmers and food insecure households. In the context of the CAR, a country grappling with severe food insecurity exacerbated by natural disasters, conflicts, and economic challenges, the project provided a multi-faceted support system aiming at the core of agricultural production. Firstly, it supplied over 329,000 farmers, 51% of whom are women, with vital agricultural inputs such as seeds, fertilizers, animal feed, small equipment, and the requisite training necessary for boosting agricultural production. This strategic input has paved the way for increased food availability, significantly contributing towards self-sufficiency and reducing dependency on food aid. Additionally, the project also focused on improving livestock health, which is vital for the livelihoods of vulnerable households. It achieved this by vaccinating and treating approximately 11,700 animals owned by these households against common diseases, preventing morbidity and mortality, and thus safeguarding their living means. These interventions, comprehensive in nature, have led to the production of about 80,000 tons of food for both personal consumption and market selling, showcasing a substantial impact in addressing food scarcity, improving livelihoods, and enhancing resilience against future crises.

project: Türkiye Climate Resilient Forests Project
description: This use case example outlines efforts to strengthen institutions and society for wildfire and forest resilience through comprehensive review and strategy development. In the context of addressing the increasing risk of wildfires in Türkiye, particularly influenced by climate change, the project focused on enhancing the effectiveness of managing and protecting the country’s forests. This involved a meticulous review of existing legislation, regulations, and policy frameworks to identify gaps and needs arising from emerging wildfire risks. The project undertook a detailed analysis of various institutional frameworks, including Forest Law, various circulars and regulations related to forest fires, and the National Forest Fires Intervention Plan. Aimed at strengthening the policy, legal, and institutional frameworks, the initiative considered factors unique to Türkiye, such as social structure, forest situations, climate change impacts, and more. By drawing from international best practices and comprehensive stakeholders' engagement, draft revisions were proposed to address identified gaps, alongside the preparation of a National Integrated Fire Management Strategy and updating strategic plans. This multifaceted approach showcases a strategic method of bolstering wildfire resilience through institutional strengthening and strategic planning.

description: This use case example details the enhancement of fire cause investigation capabilities in Türkiye to address the high rate of 'unknown' fire ignitions. The project embarked on strengthening fire investigation capabilities to support ignition risk reduction strategies. This involved a comprehensive review and analysis of laws, regulations, and current practices of fire investigation in Türkiye, alongside examining successful examples globally. Knowledge exchange on Fire Cause Investigation, including participation in international trainings and engaging with other countries, formed a vital part of this initiative. Stakeholders' consultation was conducted to outline roles, responsibilities, and collaboration for effective fire management. The result was the development of a guide and training materials on fire investigation for fire management professionals in Türkiye, ultimately aiming to significantly reduce the proportion of fires with unknown causes and enhance wildfire prevention efforts.

description: This use case example emphasizes the importance of maintaining and improving the forest road network to enhance access for wildfire management in Türkiye, particularly in the wake of the destructive 2021 wildfires. Additionally, the machinery could be utilized to maintain, repair, and open new road access in case of wildfires and help rehabilitate forest roads destroyed by other disasters. This endeavor supports the broader government's goal of increasing forest cover and combating climate change impacts. The activities encompass engaging local communities and selected farms, granting them the means to implement these practices effectively. Collectively, this pilot aims to preserve the unique plant collections and contribute to the region's ecological and agricultural resilience.

description: This use case example highlights the project's strategies to enhance resilience and inclusion in vulnerable rural areas amidst climate threats. Within the context of Moroccan rural communities, which often comprise populations living below the poverty line and relying on climate-sensitive activities such as rainfed agriculture, the project identified priority areas based on extensive analytical work. Initiatives such as the 'Solidarity Agriculture' program, the rollout of a new social protection system, and the expansion of agriculture insurance schemes for small farmers were implemented. The project also focused on the rehabilitation of oases and forest programs for watershed protection and forest fire management. Specifically, the HSFCP-Rice sub-plan addresses the unique needs of the main rice-producing provinces by categorizing rice production systems based on regional differences in climate and soil conditions—ranging from one rice crop in the Northeast to two to three crops in warmer regions. An important aspect of this project is its significant budget allocation, constituting about one-third of the overall HSFCP funds, indicative of the significant priority placed on rice production within China's agricultural sector.

description: This use case example illustrates an integrated approach to promoting green and resilient paddy production while managing environmental and social risks. Set in the backdrop of China's National High-Standard Farmland Construction Plan (2021-2030), the program aims to support a subset of activities, ranging from policy reforms, irrigation and water management improvements, nutrient management, to institutional strengthening. Notably, interventions like the adoption of smart irrigation technologies, soil testing, and fertilizer optimization strategies typify efforts to reduce reliance on chemicals, thus contributing to environmental sustainability. The program's design is cautious of environmental and social risks, excluding activities with potential adverse impacts, such as large-scale infrastructure projects that may exacerbate water scarcity. Through such exclusions and the inclusion of beneficial practices, the program works towards achieving significant positive environmental and social outcomes in participating regions, effectively balancing agricultural productivity with ecosystem health and community welfare.

project: Agriculture Governance, Growth and Resilience Investment Project
description: This use case example details the process of enhancing sector governance and agriculture knowledge management to improve policy formulation, public spending monitoring, and evaluation in the agriculture sector. In the context of the Agriculture Governance Growth and Resilience Investment Project, key institutions were digitalized, and service delivery in food quality and safety was enhanced. Efforts focused on supporting the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry, and Irrigation (MAFI) extension services, modernizing veterinary services, and strengthening linkages between business service providers and farmers. A notable initiative included upgrading the functionality of the Agency for Interventions and Payments in Agriculture (AIPA), involving technical assistance for aligning with EU fiduciary requirements, staffing reforms, technical upgrades, and digitalization efforts. Another critical sub-component was improving food safety systems, which aimed to build human, institutional, and technical capacities for food quality and safety management, aligning with EU standards. Activities encompassed regulatory support for harmonizing national frameworks with EU requirements, institutional capacity building, and technical enhancements to food safety management institutions.

project: Agriculture Governance, Growth and Resilience Investment Project
description: This use case example showcases the efforts to enhance access to agricultural knowledge among Moldovan farmers, aiming to bolster their competitiveness and ensure effective absorption of public and EU funds. In the context of fragmented and inefficient knowledge management systems, the initiative prioritized modernizing advisory services, incorporating gender-inclusive approaches, and offering customized services. The establishment of the Agricultural and Rural Advisory Center (ARAC) as the apex institution for providing consolidated advisory services was a significant step. This move was supplemented by legislative reviews, coaching programs, the development of digital tools, and the creation of an agricultural market information system. Efforts aimed to decentralize knowledge management and advisory service delivery to improve access to essential knowledge through web and mobile applications, online courses, and kiosks. A focus on climate resilience, including promoting climate-smart technologies and farming practices, was integral to revamping advisory services effectively.

project: Tanzania Food Systems Resilience Program
description: This use case example demonstrates the approach of strengthening delivery systems in agricultural research, extension, and seed dissemination. In the context of the Tanzania Food Systems Resilience Program, a multi-phase endeavor aimed at enhancing food system resilience across Eastern and Southern Africa, Phase 2 has been specifically dedicated to supporting resilience by boosting agricultural service delivery alongside the adoption of climate-resilient technologies and better fiscal performance within the agricultural sector. The program allocates US$300 million towards these objectives, with a significant focus on improving service delivery mechanisms. The operation delineates three key result areas, the first of which emphasizes refining the systems in place for agricultural research, extension services, and seed distribution through interventions such as developing sustainable financing mechanisms for climate-resilient agricultural technologies, enhancing extension outreach with Information and Communication Technology (ICT) solutions for promoting climate-smart practices, and strengthening the seed value chain. The initiative not only aims at expanding the reach of agricultural services but also at ensuring these services are effectively aligned with the needs of modern agriculture, particularly under the increasing threat of climate change.

project: Tanzania Food Systems Resilience Program
description: This use case example focuses on developing resilient rural agricultural infrastructure to support food systems resilience. Within the scope of the Tanzania Food Systems Resilience Program, a substantial element pertains to the improvement of infrastructure critical to agricultural productivity and sustainability. The program, being part of a larger, multi-phase effort spanning several countries in Eastern and Southern Africa, dedicates a portion of its US$300 million budget to this endeavor. Key interventions under this initiative include the introduction and implementation of performance-based Operations Management and Maintenance (OMM) contracts for infrastructure projects, the effective management of public warehouse facilities to improve storage capacity and reduce post-harvest losses, and the comprehensive assessment and scaling up of soil health management practices. These strategic emphases are designed to bolster the resilience of rural infrastructures against environmental stresses, thereby ensuring a more reliable and climate-adaptive agricultural framework. By facilitating more robust and sustainable structures, the program aims to foster a conducive environment for the delivery of critical agricultural services and enhance the overall productivity of the sector.
